case_vignette: A 21-year-old male presents for evaluation of a painful rash on his right index finger. He reports a tingling sensation prior to the eruption of red small spots that became more yellow and pus filled. He denies any trauma or topical products applied to the area. He has a history of cold sores on the lips. Physical examination reveals multiple clustered painful, white-yellow vesicles on the right index finger on erythematous pink base.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

I have a painful rash with red spots that turned yellow and filled with pus on my right index finger.
How long have you had the rash?
I didn't mention how long I've had the rash.

I didn't mention how long the rash has been there.

Unfortunately, I didn't say how long the rash has been there.
My apologies for the oversight. Could you please tell me for how long you have had the rash?
I'm sorry, but I didn't mention the duration of the rash.
Understood, would you be able to tell me when you first noticed the rash?
I can't tell you exactly when I first noticed it, as I didn't specify that.
I apologize for the misunderstanding. Can you please tell me when you first noticed the rash?
I can't give you a specific time for when I first noticed the rash, as I didn't provide that information.
Do you have any known allergies?
I didn't mention having any allergies.
Have you experienced similar rashes in the past?
Yes, I have a history of cold sores on my lips.
Have you come into contact with anything new or unusual recently, such as plants, animals, or chemicals?
No, I haven't had any contact with new or unusual things like plants, animals, or chemicals.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your finger?
No, I haven't had any injuries or trauma to my finger.
Is the rash on other parts of your body or only on your right index finger?
The rash is only on my right index finger.
Have you had any recent fevers, joint pain, or a history of infections?
I didn't mention any fevers, joint pain, or a history of infections.
Are there any blisters or lesions elsewhere on your body, especially around your mouth or nose?
No, there are no blisters or lesions elsewhere, except for a history of cold sores on my lips.
Have you started any new medications recently that could be related to the rash?
I didn't mention starting any new medications.
Do any of your family members have a history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I didn't mention anything about my family's medical history.
Given the painful, pustular rash on your finger and a history of cold sores, have you been previously diagnosed with a specific skin condition by a healthcare professional?
I only mentioned a history of cold sores; I didn't say if I've been diagnosed with a specific skin condition.
Considering the characteristics of your rash along with your history of cold sores, are you currently under any form of stress or experiencing an illness that might have triggered this outbreak?
I didn't mention being under stress or experiencing an illness that might have triggered the rash.
Final Diagnosis: Herpetic whitlow (herpes simplex virus infection on the finger).
